item.title: Configuring meow for Friendlier LaTeX Editing
item.description: TL;DR: We implement some configuration to recover functionality possible in evil-tex in the meow modal editing scheme. This article assumes some familiarity with the evil and meow modes. evil-tex Doing Our Own Thing Inline Math Environments LaTeX Parentheses Delimiters Closing Thoughts Having ditched evil-collection to get familiar with the vanilla emacs keybindings, I surprisingly found myself satisfied with many of the facilities emacs provides out-of-the-box for editing text. Alas, I feel modal editing is something I prefer, so I’ve adopted meow.

item.title: Configuring meow for Friendly LaTeX Editing
item.description: TL;DR: We implement some configuration to recover functionality possible in evil-tex in the meow modal editing scheme. Having ditched evil-collection to get familiar with the default emacs keybindings, I found myself satsisfied with many of the facilities emacs provides out-of-the-box for editing text. Alas, I feel modal editing is something I prefer, so I switched to meow. I chose meow for a few reasons: Trivial to extend and hack on The “selection-first” ethos is intriguing No dependencies Prefers built-in methods for various tasks Keypad mode offers a great, lighter weight alternative to the SPC DOOM leader with evil mode So far, it’s been an enjoyable experience, but one evil-mode package–evil-tex–gave me pause.

item.title: A meow-state for speedy org structure navigation
item.description: TL;DR: We implement a meow-state for quick navigation of org-mode document structure. I’ve been very pleased with my switch to the meow modal editor, but one of the downsides of it is no obvious way to use speed keys in org-mode. Namely, the meow normal state maps would clash with the speed key definitions. One could just redefine the speed keys to avoid the normal state maps, or redefine the normal state maps themselves, but that’s no fun.

item.title: Emacs org-mode for LaTeX
item.description: About four years ago, my brother introduced me to Linux and free and open source software. Around the same time I learned to use LaTeX to typeset documents with lots of mathematical notation. I then stumbled across Gilles Castel’s article on typing LaTeX with vim, and I was amazed. For those who don’t know, typing LaTeX by default is a terrible experience. Terrible. Using a program like vim with plugins made typing LaTeX so frictionless that I immediately dove into the world of extensible text editors.
